title: Alex McLeish explains why he left Birmingham City for Aston Villa: ''The goalposts shifted''
text:
McLeish has opened up on the controversial switch (Photo: Getty) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Alex McLeish has opened up on his controversial departure from Birmingham City to join fierce rivals Aston Villa in June 2011. 
The Scot led Blues to the League Cup in the previous season but they also suffered relegation to the Championship. 
He was backed by the board at St Andrew's but resigned before joining Villa just five days later. 
And McLeish now says he felt 'undermined' at Birmingham and that 'goalposts shifted' leaving him with no option but to leave the club. McLeish during his time in the Villa dugout (Photo: Dean Mouhtaropoulos) The Scot came under pressure from both sets of fans (Photo: Getty) 
“It took me by surprise,” McLeish told ESPN. 
“I was backed into a corner when I left Birmingham. I felt that I was being undermined so I had to get out. 
“The goalposts shifted and I had no alternative but to leave at the end of the season." 
McLeish came in for criticism from both sets of fans, but insists he managed to avoid the vitriol by staying away from social media. McLeish says he felt 'undermined' at St Andrew's (Photo: Getty) Read More Aston Villa striker v Paul McGrath turns into the nicest Twitter spat football has ever seen 
“But I didn’t anticipate the reaction of the fans on both sides," he added. "I’m not on social media, but by all accounts I was getting slaughtered. 
“I made sure I didn’t get any feedback on that because that would have made it even worse. 
“You don’t want to be doing training every day on a downer, with your head down.
